tit.e: Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)
tit.cmt: Such information should not be included in a title

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府（かまくらばくふ）は、源頼朝が鎌倉（現在の神奈川県鎌倉市）に創設した武家政権（幕府）である。
sen.e: Kamakura bakufu was a samurai government (bakufu) established in Kamakura (currently, Kanagawa prefecture Kamakura city) by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo.
The Kamakura Bakufu was a samurai government (bakufu) established in Kamakura (currently, Kanagawa Prefecture Kamakura City) by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo.
The Kamakura Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) was a samurai government (bakufu) established in Kamakura (currently, Kanagawa City, Kamakura Prefecture) by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo.
sen.cmt: 最初のタイトルで (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)を削除されていたので、この冒頭で附けました。Cityとprefectureの位置を交換しました。

sen.j: かつての通説によると、鎌倉幕府は、1192年（建久3年）に源頼朝が征夷大将軍（以下、将軍）に任官されて始まったとされていたが、頼朝の権力・統治機構はそれ以前から存続しており、現在ではこの説は支持されていない。
sen.e: According to an old popular theory, Kamakura bakufu was thought to have started when MINAMOTO no Yoritomo was appointed to seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") (hereinafter, shogun) but the power and governing system of Yoritomo had existed before that and now this theory is not believed.

sen.j: 今日、歴史学上では初の武家政権及び武家政治の創始は平氏政権にあるとされるが、朝廷から独立した本格的な武家政権が鎌倉幕府であることは間違いない。
sen.e: Today, from the viewpoint of historical sciences, the originator of the first samurai government and samurai politics was the Taira clan government, but it is doubtless that the full-fledged samurai government independent from Imperial Court was Kamakura bakufu.

sen.j: 当初の鎌倉幕府は東国を中心に成立した鎌倉殿を主宰者とする武士を首班とした地方政権であり、承久の乱後、全国政権へと飛躍し、権力を拡大させたものである。
sen.e: At first Kamakura bakufu was the regional government, in which Kamakura-dono established centering on Togoku presided over samurais and they were the main groups, and after Jokyu War it became a nationwide government and expanded the dominion.

The Kamakura Bakufu was originally a local government headed by the Kamakura-dono founded in the Tokoku region which presided over the samurai but rapidly developed throughout the nation and expanded its power following the Jokyu War.

sen.e: The political, military and economical base was Kanto chigyo-koku (provincial fiefdom) and Kanto domains which Yoritomo acquired by searching out and destroying the Taira clan and so on, but the essence was the Lower-ranking vassal system whose base was a feudal master-servant relationship between Kamakura-dono and gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods).

The political, military and economical base was Kanto chigyo-koku (provincial fiefdom) and Kanto domains which Yoritomo acquired by searching out and destroying the Taira clan and its allies, but the essence was the lower-ranking vassal system whose base was a feudal master-servant relationship between Kamakura-dono and gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods).

sen.j: この御家人制は平安時代以降の土地制度である荘園公領制に立脚した守護地頭制に由来し、御家人に対して先祖伝来の所領の地頭に任命する本領安堵、また武功に対して新たに地頭に人目し所領を与える新恩給与による御恩を受ける代わりに鎌倉殿の課す軍役や京都大番役、鎌倉番役を課す奉公によって成立している。
sen.e: The Lower-ranking vassal system originated from Shugo and Jito system based on shoen koryo sei (The System of Public Lands and Private Estates) which was the land system after the Heian period, and it consisted of honryo-ando (acknowledgment for inherited estate) where gokenin was appointed to Jito of the territory inherited from the ancestor and military service imposed by Kamakura-dono or the service of Kyoto obanyaku (a job to guard Kyoto) and Kamakura Banyaku (guards of Kamakura), instead of giving a favor by shinon-kyuyo (granting new domains) where Jito was newly given a territory for their deed of valor.
sen.cmt: 「地頭に人目し」の「人目」が不明でした。

sen.j: 平安時代末期、平清盛を中心とする平氏政権が成立していたが、旧勢力や対抗勢力には強い反感・抵抗感があった。
sen.e: During the end of Heian period, the Taira clan government centering on TAIRA no Kiyomori was established, but old forces and rival forces had a strong antipathy and resistance.
At the end of Heian period, the Taira clan government centered around TAIRA no Kiyomori was established, but old forces and rival forces harbored strong feelings of animosity and opposition.

sen.j: 1177年の鹿ケ谷の陰謀を嚆矢として、反平氏の動きが活発化し、1180年、後白河天皇の皇子以仁王が平氏追討の兵を挙げ、すぐ討ち取られたものの、これを契機に全国的に反平氏を標榜する勢力が立ち上がっていった。
sen.e: Firstly in the Shishigatani plot in 1177, the movement of anti-Taira clan was activated and in 1180, Mochihitoo, the prince of Emperor Goshirakawa, rose up in arms for searching out and destroying Taira clan, but was defeated immediately, which led to the rising of the forces which advocated anti-Taira nationwide.

The anti-Taira clan movement became active as a result of the Shishigatani plot in 1177 and in 1180, Mochihitoo, the son of Emperor Goshirakawa, raised an army to hunt down and destroy the Taira clan but, although he was soon defeated, this led to the rising up of forces throughout the nation who advocate opposition against the Taira clan.

sen.j: そうした状況の中で、伊豆国に流罪となっていた源頼朝は、同年8月に挙兵し石橋山の戦いで敗れたが、逃亡先の安房国から上総・下総を行軍する間に、関東一円の平氏系の武士団（坂東平氏）らの支持を獲得した。
sen.e: Under such a situation, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, who was transported to Izu province, rose up in arms in August in the same year and was defeated in Battle of Ishibashiyama, but while marching from Awa Province, his destination of escape, to Kazusa Province and Shimosa Province, he got the support of Taira clan (Heishi clan) samurai group (Bando-Heishi clan).

It was to be in these circumstances that MINAMOTO no Yoritomo who had been exiled to Izu Province raised an army in August of the same year was defeated in the Battle of Ishibashiyama but while marching from Awa Province, to which he had fled, to Kazusa Province and Shimosa Province, he gained the support of a Taira clan lineage samurai group (Bando-Heishi clan) active throughout the Kanto region.

sen.j: 瞬く間に大勢力となった頼朝軍は、同年10月、先祖ゆかりの地である鎌倉へ入り本拠地とした。
sen.e: The army of Yoritomo became a big force in a very short time and in October in the same year went into Kamakura which was associated with the ancestor and made it the home base.

sen.j: 1183年7月、源義仲が平氏を京都から追放したが、義仲勢力は推戴する北陸宮の天皇即位を迫り、京内で乱暴な行動を重ねた。
sen.e: In July, 1183 MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka expelled Taira clan from Kyoto, but his forces tried to push forward the accession to Emperor of Hokuriku no Miya and acted violently many times in Kyoto.

sen.j: これを憂慮した後白河上皇は、頼朝へ上洛を求めたが、頼朝は逆に東海道・東山道・北陸道の荘園・国衙領を元のように国司・本所に返還させる内容の宣旨（寿永二年十月宣旨）の発給を要求した。
sen.e: Worrying this, the retired Emperor Goshirakawa asked Yoritomo to come to Kyoto, but instead Yoritomo asked the issuance of the declaration (Juei-ninen Jugatsu no Senji) which ordered shoen (manor in medieval Japan) and Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office) along Tokai-do Road, Tosan-do Road and Hokuriku-do Road to be returned to kokushi (provincial governors) and honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor).

Concerned by this, Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa requested that Yoritomo come to Kyoto, but instead Yoritomo requested that the issue of the declaration (Juei-ninen Jugatsu no Senji) ordering shoen (manors in medieval Japan) and Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office) in Tokai-do, Tosan-do and Hokuriku-do to be returned to kokushi (provincial governors) and honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor).

sen.j: 同時に、頼朝は弟の源範頼・源義経を派遣し、平氏追討に当たらせ、1185年、壇ノ浦の戦いで平氏が滅亡し、6年に渡る内乱が終結した。

sen.j: 同年、源義経・源行家が頼朝政権の内規に違反したことを契機に、頼朝は両者追討の院宣を後白河法皇から獲得するとともに、両者の追捕を名目に、守護・地頭の任免権を承認させた。
sen.e: In the same year, when MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune and MINAMOTO no Yukiie breached the bylaw of Yoritomo administration, Yoritomo got inzen (a decree from the retired Emperor) to search out and destroy both of them from the retired Emperor Goshirakawa and in the name of capturing both of them, Yoritomo made Goshirakawa approve the right of the appointment and dismissal of Shugo and Jito.

sen.e: In 1190 Yoritomo was appointed to Ukone no daisho (Major Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards), the highest job of regular military officers, but the job collaterally had various political constraints and thus he quitted it soon and hoped to be seii taishogun who had a higher degree of freedom.

In 1190 Yoritomo was appointed Ukone no daisho (Major Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards), the highest job of regular military officers, but the post was associated with various political constraints and he therefore soon resigned, hoping to become shogun with the higher degree of freedom that the position afforded.

sen.e: Yoritomo's direct descendant was extinguished and the bakufu was worried and requested for Imperial Prince shogun to Imperial Court, but Chiten no kimi (the retired emperor in power), the Emperor Gotoba refused it and through many gyrations an infant of Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents), FUJIWARA no Yoritsune, who was distantly-related with Yoritomo, was welcomed as a new shogun = Kamakura-dono.

sen.j: 1224年に北条義時、1225年に北条政子や大江広元といった幕府創業世代が死去し、義時の子北条泰時が執権となった。

sen.e: Yasutoki appointed his ankle Tokifusa HOJO to rensho (assistant to regents) in order to prevent the confusion during generation change and set hyojoshu (a member of Council of State) which was the council system for political decisions and established the collective leadership system.

In order to prevent confusion during the transition of power to the next generation, Yasutoki appointed his uncle, Tokifusa HOJO, as rensho (assistant to the shikken), established the hyojoshu - a consulting institution for making political decisions - and founded the collective leadership system.

sen.j: また、泰時は、式目制定に当たって、朝廷の司法権を侵害するものでないことを強調している。

sen.j: こうした泰時の一連の施策は、執権政治の確立と捉えられている。
sen.e: These series of measures by Yasutoki was regarded as the establishment of Shikken politics.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府は、頼朝以来、鎌倉殿の個人的な資質に依拠するところが大きく、その組織も鎌倉殿の家政機関を発展させただけのものだった。
sen.e: Kamakura bakufu had largely depended on a personal character of Kamakura-dono and the organization only developed from a domestic governing institution of Kamakura-dono.

sen.j: しかし、泰時が確立した集団指導体制・明確な法令による司法体制は、個人的な資質などの不安定な要素に左右されることはなく、安定した政治結果を生み出すものだった。
sen.e: However, the judicial system by collective leadership system and clear codes established by Yasutoki was not determined by unstable factors such as a personal character and so on and gave rise to stable political results.

sen.j: 泰時の孫北条時頼は、泰時の執権政治を継承していった。

sen.e: Yasutoki focused on the reinforcement of judicial system and in 1249 he set Hikitsukeshu (Coadjustor of the High Court) to make the court fair.

sen.j: 1246年、時頼排除を企てた前将軍・藤原頼経と名越光時一派を幕府から追放する（宮騒動）と、1247年には有力御家人である三浦泰村の一族を討滅した（宝治合戦）。
sen.e: In 1246 Tokiyori expelled a group of the former shogun FUJIWARA no Yoritsune and Mitsutoki NAGOE from bakufu because they tried to eliminate Tokiyori (Miya-sodo (ailed attempt at rebellion)) and in 1247 he eradicated a family of Yasumura MIURA who was a senior vassal (Battle of Hoji).

sen.j: 1252年、幕府への謀叛に荷担した将軍藤原頼嗣が廃され、代わりに宗尊親王を新将軍として迎えることに成功した。
sen.e: In 1252 FUJIWARA no Yoritsugu, who had a part in a rebellion against bakufu, was abolished and instead he succeeded in welcoming Imperial Prince Munetaka as a new shogun.

sen.j: これ以後、親王将軍（宮将軍）が代々迎えられ、親王将軍は幕府の政治に参与しないことが通例となった。
sen.e: After this Imperial Prince shogun (miyashogun (shogun from the Imperial Court)) was welcomed from generation to generation and Imperial Prince shogun did not take part in politics of bakufu as a rule.
Following this, successive generations of Imperial Prince shogun (miyashogun (shogun from the Imperial Court)) was welcomed but generally did not participate in bakufu politics.

sen.j: こうして、親王将軍の下で専制を強めていった北条氏は、権力を北条宗家へ集中させていった。
sen.e: Like this, Hojo clan came to strengthen the despotic government under Imperial Prince shoguns and focused the power on Muneie HOJO.
It was due to this that the Hojo clan which had come to strengthen its autocratic rule under Imperial Prince shogun conferred most of its power the power on Muneie HOJO.

sen.j: 時頼は、病のため執権職を北条氏支流の北条長時に譲ったが、実権を握り続けた。
sen.e: Because of illness, Tokiyori ceded the Shikken job to Nagatoki HOJO who was in the branch of the Hojo clan, but continued to hold the real power.
Because of illness, Tokiyori ceded the position of shikken to Nagatoki HOJO, member of a branch of the Hojo clan, but he continued to hold the real power.

sen.j: これにより政治の実権は執権の地位と乖離していく。
sen.e: Likewise, the real power of politics lost touch with the Shikken status.
Thus actual political power diverged from the position of shikken.

sen.j: 北条宗家を当時、得宗（徳宗）と呼んだことから、上記の政治体制を得宗専制という。
sen.e: Because in those days Muneie HOJO was called Tokuso (the patrimonial head of the main branch of the Hojo clan), the above political system was called Tokuso tyranny (a tyranny of the patrimonial head of the main branch of the Hojo clan).

sen.e: Because Muneie HOJO was called Tokuso at the time, the above political system is referred to as the Tokuso autocracy.

sen.j: 時頼の死後、得宗の地位を継いだのは子の北条時宗だった。
sen.e: After Tokiyori died, it was Tokimune HOJO that succeeded the status of Tokuso.

sen.j: 時宗が得宗となった前後の1268年、モンゴル帝国第5代大ハーンのクビライが高麗を通して朝貢を要求してきた。
sen.e: Around 1268 when Tokimune became a Tokuso, Kublai (the 5th Khan of the Mongol Empire) asked for tributes through Goryeo.

sen.j: 朝廷は対応を幕府へ一任し、幕府は回答しないことを決定、西国の防御を固めることとした。
sen.e: Imperial Court left the correspondence to bakufu and the bakufu decided not to answer and strengthened the protection in Saigoku.
The Imperial Court entrusted the matter to the bakucu which decided not to respond but instead strengthened the defense of Saigoku.

sen.j: 1269年と1271年にもモンゴルから国書が届き、朝廷は返書送付を提案したが、幕府は当初の方針どおり黙殺を選んだ（外交権も幕府が握っていたことを表す）。
sen.e: The sovereign's messages came from Mongol in 1269 and 1271 and Imperial Court suggested the reply, but the bakufu chose to ignore them following the original policy (which means that the foreign diplomacy was also grasped by bakufu).

sen.j: モンゴルから国号を改めた元 (王朝)は、1274年（文永11）10月に九州北部を襲撃したが、数日で撤退した（今日では、文永の役における元軍の撤退理由が暴風雨、いわゆる神風が吹いたためとする説は信憑性が低いとされ、威力偵察が主目的であったとされる）。
sen.e: Yuan Dynasty, whose name was changed from Mongol, attacked the north part of Kyushu in October 1274, but after a few days retreated (today, it has a low credibility that the reason of retreat of the Yuan army in Bunei War was severe storm, that is, kamikaze (divine wind) and it is considered that the main purpose was to reconnoiter the military power).

sen.j: これを文永の役という。

sen.j: 幕府は朝廷と一体になって、国家鎮護に当たることとし、西国の警固を再強化するとともに、それまで幕府の支配の及ばなかった朝廷側の支配地、本所一円地からの人員・兵粮の調達が認められるようになった。
sen.e: Bakufu collaborated with Imperial Court for the protection of the nation and was approved to get personnel and military provisions from Imperial Court's territories and honjo ichienchi (over the territory of the Imperial court), which had been out of control of bakufu, as well as strengthening again the protection in Saigoku.

sen.j: 元は1281年（弘安4）夏に再度、九州北部を中心に日本への侵略を試みた。

sen.j: この時は1ヶ月以上にわたる鎌倉方の頑強な抵抗に遭い、侵攻が停滞していたところに台風による大被害を受けて元軍は敗退した。
sen.e: This assault met the strong resistance of Kamakura side for more than one month and the typhoon inflicted heavy damage on Yuan army when the invasion slumbered and the army retreated.

sen.j: 前回の襲来と併せて元寇と呼ぶ。
sen.e: With the previous assault, they are called Mongol invasion attempts against Japan.
This and the previous assault are collectively referred to as the Mongol invasions of Japan.

sen.j: この間、時宗は非常事態への迅速な対処を名目として、時間のかかる合議ではなく、一門や側近（御内人という）らと専断で政策決定していった。
sen.e: During this time, in the name of rapid coping with emergency, Tokimune decided the policies on his own authority not in a parliamentary system which took lots of time to decide, but with his families or close advisers (called Miuchibito (private vassals of the tokuso)).

sen.e: Meanwhile, Uchi-Kanrei (head of Tokuso Family), who was the top of Miuchibito, began to have the power gradually and during Koan period, a Uchi-Kanrei TAIRA no Yoritsuna and a senior vassal Yasumori ADACHI opposed to each other.

sen.j: 泰盛は、時宗の理解も得て、幕府の経済基盤の充実を図るとともに、御家人の地位を保証する政策を実現しようとした。
sen.e: Yasumori, with the understanding of Tokimune, tried to implement the policy to guarantee the status of gokenin, as well as enriching the economical base of bakufu

sen.j: しかし、時宗が1284年に急死すると、翌1285年、平頼綱は泰盛を突如襲撃・殺害し、泰盛派の御家人らを討伐した（霜月騒動）。
sen.e: However, when Tokimune died suddenly in 1284, TAIRA no Yoritsuna suddenly assaulted Yasumori and killed him and exterminated the gokenins of Yasumori side in the next 1285 (the Shimotsuki Incident).

sen.j: この頃、朝廷においては、後嵯峨天皇以後の皇位を巡って大覚寺統と持明院統の2系統に分立して幕府に皇位継承の調整を求めた。
sen.e: During this time, Imperial Court, divided into the two parties of Daikakuji-to (imperial lineage starting with Emperor Kameyama) and Jimyoin-to (imperial lineage from Emperor Gofukakusa to Emperor Gokomatsu) concerning imperial succession after the Emperor Gosaga, asked for the adjustment to bakufu.

During this time, the Imperial Court had split into the Daikakuji-to (imperial lineage starting with Emperor Kameyama) and Jimyoin-to (imperial lineage from Emperor Gofukakusa to Emperor Gokomatsu) lineages, and requested that the bakufu arrange the affairs of imperial succession.

sen.cmt: 後嵯峨天皇以後の皇位を巡って が抜けているので追加し文脈修正。

sen.j: 幕府は両統迭立原則を示して仲裁にあたるとともに内外の危機に対応するために幕府は朝廷に対しても「徳政」と呼ばれる政治改革を要求した。
sen.e: The bakufu asked for a political reform called "Tokusei " (virtuous rule) also to Imperial Court to cope with the crisis of both foreign and domestic as well as mediating both of the parties with the indication of principle of both parties' alternate compatibility.

The bakufu asked for a political reform called "Tokusei " (virtuous rule) also to Imperial Court to cope with the crisis of both foreign and domestic as well as mediating both of the parties with the indication of principle of both parties' alternate compatibility.

The bakufu tried to mediate between both parties, suggesting that a principle of ryoto tetsuritsu (alternate accession from two ancestries of imperial families) be adopted; at the same time, the bakufu also urged the Imperial Court to undertake a political reform called "Tokusei " (virtuous rule) in order to deal with both the internal and external crises.

sen.j: これを受けて亀山上皇は1286年（弘安9）12月に院評定を徳政沙汰と雑訴沙汰に分割、続いて伏見天皇は1293年（正応6）6月に記録所組織の改革を行って、政治組織の刷新を行って円滑な政務遂行を図った。
sen.e: Answering this, the retired Emperor Kameyama divided In no hyojo (consultation under the government by the retired Emperor) into tokusei-sata (dealing with problems related to religious matters and official appointments) and zasso sata (litigation investigation) and the Emperor Fushimi reformed the organization of Kirokusho (government agency of lawsuits) in June 1293 and did government practices smoothly by the renewal of political system.

In response to this, Retired Emperor Kameyama divided In no hyojo (consultation under the government by the retired Emperor) into tokusei-sata (dealing with problems related to religious matters and official appointments) and zasso sata (litigation investigation) and the Emperor Fushimi reformed the organization of Kirokusho (government agency of lawsuits) in June 1293 and aimed for the smooth implementation of government duties by the renewal of political system.

sen.j: だが、皇位継承と徳政実施の過程において幕府との対立が表面化するようになり、朝廷内に再び反幕府の動きを潜在化させる遠因となった。
sen.e: However, during the process of imperial succession and implementation of Tokusei, the discord with bakufu surfaced and indirectly made the anti-bakufu movement be submerged again in Imperial Court.

sen.j: 平頼綱は、時宗を継いだ年少の北条貞時を補佐し、得宗専制の強化に尽力した。
sen.e: TAIRA no Yoritsuna supported juvenile Sadatoki HOJO, who succeeded Tokimune, and tried hard to strengthen Tokuso tyranny.

sen.j: 元寇防衛に働いた九州御家人の恩賞・訴訟を判定するため、安達泰盛は九州に合議制の奉行（鎮西談議所）を置いていたが、頼綱はそれに代えて、得宗派で固めた新機関（鎮西探題）を設置した。

Sadatoki HOJO, who reached adulthood in 1293, eliminated the family of TAIRA no Yoritsuna (Heizenmon Incident).
Sadatoki HOJO, who reached adulthood in 1293, eliminated the family of TAIRA no Yoritsuna (Heizenmon Incident).

sen.j: 貞時は、政治の実権を内管領から取り戻し、実質的な得宗専制を一層強化していった。
sen.e: Sadatoki got back the real political power from Uchi-Kanrei and furthermore strengthened Tokuso tyranny substantially.
Sadatoki regained real political power from Uchi-Kanrei and further strengthened the Tokuso autocracy.
Sadatoki regained real political power from Uchi-Kanrei and further strengthened the Tokuso autocracy.

sen.j: まず、頼綱政権下で停滞していた訴訟の迅速な処理のため、合議制の引付衆を廃止し、判決を全て貞時が下すこととした。
sen.e: Firstly, for rapid processings for lawsuits which were stagnated under the Yoritsuna administration, the council system Hikitsukeshu (Coadjustor of the High Court) was abolished and Sadatoki pronounced all the judgments.

Firstly, for the rapid processing of lawsuits which stagnated under the Yoritsuna administration, the Hikitsukeshu (Coadjustor of the High Court) council system was abolished and all judgments were passed by Sadatok.

Firstly, for the rapid processing of lawsuits which stagnated under the Yoritsuna administration, the Hikitsukeshu (Coadjustor of the High Court) council system was abolished and all judgments were passed by Sadatok.

sen.j: 当初、御家人らは訴訟の進行を歓迎したが、ほどなく独裁的な判決への反発が高まった。
sen.e: At first gokenins welcomed the advancement of lawsuits, but soon backlash of despotic judgments was uplifted.
At first, gokenin welcomed the advancement of lawsuits, but a backlash against autocratic judgment soon emerged.
At first, gokenin welcomed the advancement of lawsuits, but a backlash against autocratic judgment soon emerged.

sen.j: そして、1297年（永仁5）、大彗星が現れると世相に不安が拡がり、当時の徳政観念に従って、貞時は、財物を元の持ち主へ無償で帰属させる永仁の徳政令を発布した。
sen.e: When a big comet appeared in 1297 anxiety spread across social situation and following Tokusei concept in those days, Sadatoki issued Einin no Tokuseirei (a debt cancellation order) by which properties had to be returned to the original owner without compensation.

When a large comet appeared in 1297, anxiety spread across society, and, according to the Tokusei concept of the time, Sadatoki issued the Einin no Tokuseirei (a debt cancellation order) by which properties had to be returned to the original owner without compensation.

When a large comet appeared in 1297, anxiety spread across society, and, according to the Tokusei concept of the time, Sadatoki issued the Einin no Tokuseirei (a debt cancellation order) by which properties had to be returned to the original owner without compensation.

sen.j: この徳政令は、当時、普及しつつあった貨幣経済に深刻な影響を与えるとともに、社会に大きな動揺をもたらした。
sen.e: The Tokuseirei deeply influenced money economy prevalent in those days and largely upset the society.
The Tokuseirei deeply influenced monetary economy prevalent at the time, bringing great unrest to the society.
The Tokuseirei deeply influenced monetary economy prevalent at the time, bringing great unrest to the society.

sen.j: その後、執権職は貞時に代わって北条氏支流の4人が次々に受け継いだが、貞時は得宗として幕府を実質的に支配し続けた。
sen.e: After that, instead of Sadatoki, the four men of the branch of the Hojo clan succeeded the Shikken job in sequence, but Sadatoki continued to substantively govern the bakufu as Tokuso.
After that, instead of Sadatoki, the four men of the branch of the Hojo clan succeeded the Shikken job in sequence, but Sadatoki continued to substantively govern the bakufu as Tokuso.

After this, when Sadatoki left the position of Shikken (regent), he was succeeded by four men from the branch line of the Hojo clan in succession; Sadatoki himself retained the position of Tokuso (patrimonial head of the main branch of the Hojo clan), however, which means that he held the real power to control the bakufu.

sen.j: 貞時の時代には、北条一門の知行国が著しく増加した。
sen.e: During Sadatoki's period, chigyo-koku (provincial fiefdom) of the Hojo family dramatically increased.
During the time of Sadatoki, the number of chigyo-koku (provincial fiefdoms) held by the Hojo family dramatically increased.
During the time of Sadatoki, the number of chigyo-koku (provincial fiefdoms) held by the Hojo family dramatically increased.

sen.j: その一方、一般の御家人層では、異国警固番役や長門警固番役などの新たな負担を抱えるとともに、貨幣経済の普及に十分対応しきれず、分割相続による所領の細分化などもあり、急速に階層分化が進んでいった。
sen.e: On the other hand, for a common gokenin class, new burdens such as Ikokukeigobanyaku (military service imposed to gokenin in the Kyushu area by bakufu in order to provide against the invasion of Yuan dynasty) and Nagato keigoban (the guards against the invasion of a foreign country in Nagato Province) and so on were added to them and they could not cope with spread of money economy and there was segmentation of territories by division of succession and so on, and thus the differentiation of social hierarchy rapidly advanced.

On the other hand, for a common gokenin class, new burdens such as Ikokukeigobanyaku (military service imposed to gokenin in the Kyushu area by bakufu in order to provide against the invasion of Yuan dynasty) and Nagato keigoban (the guards against the invasion of a foreign country in Nagato Province) and so on were added to them and they could not cope with spread of money economy and there was segmentation of territories by division of succession and so on, and thus the differentiation of social hierarchy rapidly advanced.

On the other hand, common gokenin had to shoulder new burdens such as Ikokukeigobanyaku (military service imposed on gokenin in the Kyushu area by the bakufu in order to protect themselves against the invasion force of the Yuan dynasty) and Nagato keigoban (guards to protect Nagato Province against an invasion by a foreign country), which made it difficult for them to cope with the emerging monetary economy; moreover, their territories were broken up due to divided inheritance, so the social hierarchy rapidly diversified.

sen.j: 中には所領を増加させる御家人もいたが、没落傾向にある御家人も少なくなく、所領を売却したり、質入するなどして失い、幕府への勤仕ができない無足御家人も増加していった。
sen.e: Among the gokenins, some increased the territories and many of others were on the decline, and musoku gokenin (vassal without territory) increased, who sold or pawned their territories and so on and could not work for bakufu.

Some gokenin, some increased the number of territories they held but a considerable number went into decline, with an increase in the number of musoku gokenin (a vassal without territory) who sold or pawned their territories and were unable to work for bakufu.

Some gokenin, some increased the number of territories they held but a considerable number went into decline, with an increase in the number of musoku gokenin (a vassal without territory) who sold or pawned their territories and were unable to work for bakufu.

sen.j: こうした御家人や彼らから所領を買収・取得した武士・百姓らは悪党化し、社会変動を一層進展させた。
sen.e: These gokenin or samurai and farmers, who bought and acquired the territories from them, became Akuto (a villain in the medieval times) and thus social change dramatically advanced.
These gokenin or samurai as well as the samurai and commoners who bought or acquired their land became akuto (a villain during the middle ages), further advancing social change.
These gokenin or samurai as well as the samurai and commoners who bought or acquired their land became akuto (a villain during the middle ages), further advancing social change.

sen.j: 1311年、貞時が死去すると、子の北条高時が跡を継いだ。
sen.e: In 1311 when Sadatoki died, his son Takatoki HOJO succeeded him.
When Sadatoki died in 1311, his son Takatoki HOJO succeeded him.
When Sadatoki died in 1311, his son Takatoki HOJO succeeded him.

sen.j: 9歳の高時の補佐役に、平頼綱の一族の長崎円喜（長崎円喜）と、安達一族の生き残りの安達時顕が就いた。
sen.e: Enki NAGASAKI of TAIRA no Yoritsuna's family and Tokiaki ADACHI of a survivor of ADACHI family were appointed to the assistant of Takatoki at the age of nine.
Enki NAGASAKI of TAIRA no Yoritsuna's family and Tokiaki ADACHI, a survivor of the Adachi family were appointed as assistants to the nine-year-old Takatoki.
Enki NAGASAKI of TAIRA no Yoritsuna's family and Tokiaki ADACHI, a survivor of the Adachi family were appointed as assistants to the nine-year-old Takatoki.

sen.j: 当時、悪党と呼ばれる新興勢力が現れ、寺社の強訴が相次いでいたが、長崎高綱・安達時顕が支える得宗政権は、これらの動きに高圧的な姿勢で対処した。
sen.e: In those days, newly emerging forces called Akuto appeared and direct petitions of temples and shrines occurred one after another, but Tokuso administration supported by Takatsuna NAGASAKI and Tokiaki ADACHI coped with these movements with an authoritative attitude.

In those days, newly emerging forces called Akuto appeared and direct petitions of temples and shrines occurred one after another, but Tokuso administration supported by Takatsuna NAGASAKI and Tokiaki ADACHI coped with these movements with an authoritative attitude.

In those days, local outlaws known as Akuto emerged as a powerful force, and one after another of the temples and shrines began to appeal directly to the bakufu for help; however, the Tokuso administration, which was supported by Takatsuna NAGASAKI and Tokiaki ADACHI, responded to these appeals in a high-handed manner.

sen.j: 成人して政務に就いた高時も、こうした態度を継承し、各地で見られた地域独自の動きを強権的に押さえ込もうとした。
sen.e: Takatoki, who arrived at manhood and began government practices, inherited these attitude and tried to suppress with an iron fist the movements unique to the regions seen in various areas.
Takatoki, who had reached adulthood and become engaged in government affairs, inherited this attitude and attempted to suppress the movements in various areas with an iron fist.
Takatoki, who had reached adulthood and become engaged in government affairs, inherited this attitude and attempted to suppress the movements in various areas with an iron fist.

sen.j: しかし、このような強権的な支配では各地域の動きは抑えられず、次第に矛盾が大きくなっていった。
sen.e: However, such an authoritative governance could not suppress the movements in various areas and the contradiction became larger increasingly.
However, such an despotic governance could not suppress the movements in various areas and the conflicts became increasingly larger.
However, such an despotic governance could not suppress the movements in various areas and the conflicts became increasingly larger.

tit.j: 後醍醐天皇の倒幕運動
tit.e: The Emperor Godaigo's movement to overthrow the Shogunate.
Emperor Go-Daigo's Movement to Overthrow the Bakufu
Emperor Godaigo's Movement to Overthrow the Bakufu
tit.cmt: 用語共有に沿い、Go-DaigoをGodaigoに戻しました。

sen.j: そこに登場したのが、後醍醐天皇だった。
sen.e: It was the Emperor Godaigo who appeared at that time.
Emperor Go-Daigo appeared during this time.
Emperor Go-Daigo appeared during this time.

sen.j: 後醍醐は即位すると、天皇を中心とする政治体制の再構築を企てた。
sen.e: After Godaigo acceded to the imperial throne, he tried to restructure a political system centering on the Emperor.
After ascending to the imperial throne, he attempted to restructure a political system centering on the Emperor.
After ascending to the imperial throne, he attempted to restructure a political system centering on the Emperor.

sen.j: こうした後醍醐の姿勢は皇位継承問題をきっかけとして幕府の得宗専制と衝突することとなり、1324年（正中 (元号)1）、後醍醐の蜂起計画が露呈し、側近の公家が処罰された（正中の変）。
sen.e: Such a Godaigo's attitude collided with Tokuso tyranny of bakufu through the problem of succession to the Imperial Throne and in 1324 the uprising plan of Godaigo was revealed and kuge, his close advisers, were punished (Shochu Disturbance).

Such a Godaigo's attitude collided with Tokuso tyranny of bakufu through the problem of succession to the Imperial Throne and in 1324 the uprising plan of Godaigo was revealed and kuge, his close advisers, were punished (Shochu Disturbance).

Godaigo's attempt to achieve political reform was motivated by a desire to avoid problems regarding the imperial succession, but this created conflict with the Tokuso autocracy of the bakufu, and in 1324 Godaigo's plan to lead an uprising was revealed, and the kuge who served as his close advisers were punished (Shochu Disturbance).

sen.j: 諦めない後醍醐は、1331年（元弘1）、倒幕計画を立てたがこれも事前に発覚し、翌年隠岐島へ流された。
sen.e: Godaigo, who did not give up, planned to overthrow the bakufu, but it was also revealed in advance and he was transported to Oki no shima Island in the next year.
Emperor Go-Daigo did not give up and planned to overthrow the bakufu, but his plot was exposed and he was exiled to Oki no shima Island in the following year.
Emperor Godaigo did not give up and planned to overthrow the bakufu, but his plot was exposed and he was exiled to Oki no shima Island in the following year.
sen.cmt: 用語共有に沿い、Go-DaigoをGodaigoに戻しました。

sen.j: しかし、これを契機に得宗専制に不満を持つ楠木正成、赤松円心など各地の悪党と呼ばれる武士が各地で反幕府の兵を挙げるようになる。
sen.e: However, taking this opportunity, samurais called Akuto in various areas, such as Masashige KUSUNOKI, Enshin AKAMATSU and so on, who had disgruntled about Tokuso tyranny, rose in arms against the bakufu in various areas.

However, samurai known as akuto in various areas, including Masashige KUSUNOKI and Enshin AKAMATSU, were dissatisfied with the Tokusho autocracy and raise forces opposed to the bakufu throughout the country.

However, samurai known as akuto in various areas, including Masashige KUSUNOKI and Enshin AKAMATSU, were dissatisfied with the Tokusho autocracy and raise forces opposed to the bakufu throughout the country.

sen.j: 1333年（元弘3/正慶2）、反幕府勢力の討伐のために京都へ派遣された有力御家人の足利尊氏が、一転して後醍醐側へつき六波羅探題を落とすと、新田義貞が上野国で挙兵し、これに呼応した関東の御家人たちと鎌倉を攻略して、鎌倉幕府と北条氏は滅亡した（元弘の乱）。
sen.e: In 1333, a senior vassal Takauzi ASHIKAGA, who had been sent to Kyoto to exterminate the anti-bakufu forces, suddenly went over to Godaigo side and abolished Rokuhara Tandai, and then Yoshisada NITTA rose in arms in Kozuke Province and with Kanto gokenins, who corresponded with this, Yoshisada captured Kamakura and thus Kamakura bakufu and the Hojo clan were subverted (Genko War).

In 1333, when a senior vassal named Takauzi ASHIKAGA who had been dispatched to Kyoto to eliminate the anti-bakufu forces defected to the Go-Daigo faction and deposed the Rokuhara Tandai, Yoshisada NITTA raised an army in Kozuke Province and with Kanto gokenin, who agreed to this, captured Kamakura and thus overthrew the Kamakura bakufu and the Hojo clan (Genko War).

In 1333, when a senior vassal named Takauzi ASHIKAGA who had been dispatched to Kyoto to eliminate the anti-bakufu forces defected to the Godaigo faction and deposed the Rokuhara Tandai, Yoshisada NITTA raised an army in Kozuke Province and with Kanto gokenin, who agreed to this, captured Kamakura and thus overthrew the Kamakura bakufu and the Hojo clan (Genko War).
sen.cmt: 用語共有に沿い、Go-DaigoをGodaigoに戻しました。

sen.j: 後醍醐は京都へ帰還し親政を開始した（建武の新政）。
sen.e: Godaigo went back to Kyoto and began Shinsei (Government rule of a state by the direct administration of the Emperor) (Kenmu Restoration).
Go-Daigo returned to Kyoto and began Shinsei (Government rule of a state by the direct administration of the Emperor) (Kenmu Restoration).
Godaigo returned to Kyoto and began Shinsei (Government rule of a state by the direct administration of the Emperor) (Kenmu Restoration).
sen.cmt: 用語共有に沿い、Go-DaigoをGodaigoに戻しました。

tit.e: The principle of existence and bakufu system.
The Principle of Existence and the Bakufu System
The Principle of Existence and the Bakufu System

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府の存立は、武士、特に関東武士団を基盤としていた。
sen.e: The existence of Kamakura bakufu was based on samurais, especially Kanto Samurai Group.
The existence of Kamakura bakufu was based on samurai, especially Kanto Samurai Group.
The existence of Kamakura bakufu was based on samurai, especially Kanto Samurai Group.

sen.j: これらの武士は、「鎌倉殿」（＝将軍）の家人となることで、鎌倉幕府の構成員となった。
sen.e: These samurais became Kenin (retainers) of "Kamakura-dono" (= shogun) and became the members of Kamakura bakufu.
These samurai became kenin (retainers) of the Kamakura-dono (= shogun) and became the members of Kamakura bakufu.
These samurai became kenin (retainers) of the Kamakura-dono (= shogun) and became the members of Kamakura bakufu.

sen.j: 鎌倉殿の家人になった武士は御家人と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Samurais who became Kenin of Kamakura-domo were called gokenin.
Samurai who became kenin of the Kamakura-dono were called gokenin.
Samurai who became kenin of the Kamakura-dono were called gokenin.

sen.j: 鎌倉殿と御家人の主従関係は、御恩と奉公と呼ばれる互恵関係によって保持された、この制度を御家人制度と呼ぶ。
sen.e: The master-servant relationship between Kamakura-dono and gokenin was preserved by a reciprocal relation called favor and service and this system is called Lower-ranking vassal system.
The master-servant relationship between the Kamakura-dono and gokenin was preserved by a reciprocal relationship called "favor and service," a system known as the lower-ranking vassal system.
The master-servant relationship between the Kamakura-dono and gokenin was preserved by a reciprocal relationship called "favor and service," a system known as the lower-ranking vassal system.

sen.j: 御恩
sen.e: Favor
Favor
Favor

sen.j: 鎌倉殿が御家人の所領支配を保障し、又は新たな土地給与を行うことを言う。
sen.e: It means that Kamakura-dono guaranteed the governance of territories by gokenins and supplied them with new lands.
The Kamakura-dono guaranteed the governance of territories by gokenin and supplied them with new land.
The Kamakura-dono guaranteed the governance of territories by gokenin and supplied them with new land.

sen.j: 「御恩」には所領支配を保障する本領安堵（ほんりょうあんど）と新たな土地給与である新恩給与（しんおんきゅうよ）の2種類があった。
sen.e: In "favor" there were the two kinds, such as honryo-ando (acknowledgment for inherited estate) and shinon-kyuyo (granting new domains).
Favors consisted of both honryo-ando (acknowledgment of inherited estates) and shinon-kyuyo (the granting new domains).
Favors consisted of both honryo-ando (acknowledgment of inherited estates) and shinon-kyuyo (the granting new domains).

sen.j: いずれも御家人を地頭へ任命するという形で行われた。
sen.e: These two were done in the form of appointing gokenin to Jito.
Both were performed by appointing gokenin as Jito.
Both were performed by appointing gokenin as Jito.

sen.j: 奉公
sen.e: Service
Service
Service

sen.j: 御家人が鎌倉殿に対して負担する軍役・経済負担などを言う。
sen.e: It referred to military and economical burdens which gokenin owed to Kamakura-dono.
The military and economical burdens which gokenin owed to the Kamakura-dono.
The military and economical burdens which gokenin owed to the Kamakura-dono.

sen.j: 具体的には、「いざ鎌倉」などに代表される緊急時の軍役、内裏の警護である大番役、幕府の警護である大番役、後の元寇の頃には異国警固番役や長門警固番役という形で行われ、また関東御公事と言われる経済負担もあった。
sen.e: Specifically, there were military services during emergency such as "Iza, Kamakura" (Case that something major happens, event of an emergency, when it comes to the crunch) and so on, Obanyaku (a job to guard Kyoto) which was a protection for dairi (Imperial Palace) or bakufu, Ikokukeigobanyaku and Nagato keigoban during later Mongol invasion and Kanto-mikuji which was an economical burden.

Specifically, there was military service during emergencies such as "Iza, Kamakura" (mobilization to Kamakura at the time of emergency), Obanyaku (the job of guarding Kyoto) to protect for dairi (Imperial Palace) or bakufu, Ikokukeigobanyaku and Nagato keigoban during later Mongol invasions, and Kanto-mikuji which was an economic burden.

Specifically, there was military service during emergencies such as "Iza, Kamakura" (mobilization to Kamakura at the time of emergency), Obanyaku (the job of guarding Kyoto) to protect for dairi (Imperial Palace) or bakufu, Ikokukeigobanyaku and Nagato keigoban during later Mongol invasions, and Kanto-mikuji which was an economic burden.

sen.j: 以上のように、相互に利益を享受することで、両者は結ばれていた。
sen.e: Like this, both were connected by benefiting each other.
It was in this way that both parties were connected in a mutually beneficial relationship.
It was in this way that both parties were connected in a mutually beneficial relationship.

sen.j: 主従の契約は、御家人が鎌倉殿へ見参した際の名簿差出（みょうぶさしだし）によって行われ、幕府は御家人名簿により御家人を管理した。
sen.e: The contract of master-servant relationship was managed by Myobu (identification) offered by a gokenin who visited Kamakura-dono and the bakufu supervised gokenins by Gokenin Meibo (name list of retainers).

The master-servant relationship contract was managed by myobu (a piece of wood with a name inscribed on it) offered by a gokenin who visited Kamakura-dono, and the bakufu supervised gokenin using the Gokenin Meibo (name list of retainers).

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府は、以下のような独自の経済基盤を有していた。
sen.e: Kamakura bakufu had a unique economical base as follows.
The Kamakura Bakufu possessed the following economic bases.

sen.j: 関東御成敗地 - 将軍家が地頭任免権を持つ国・荘園・国衙領
sen.e: Kanto goseibaichi - provinces, manors and Kokugaryo where the shogun families of Kamakura bakufu possessed the power to appoint/dismiss Jito.
Kanto goseibaichi - provinces, manors and kokugaryo for which the shogun family possessed the power to appoint/dismiss Jito.

sen.e: Kanto domains - manors whose honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor) was shogun.
Kanto domains - manors whose honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor) was shogun.
Kanto domains - manors whose honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor) was shogun.

sen.j: 関東御分国 - 将軍に与えられた知行国
sen.e: Kanto gobunkoku - provincial territories belonged to the Kamakura Bakufu.
Kanto gobunkoku - provincial territories belonging to the Kamakura Bakufu.

sen.j: 関東進止所領 - 将軍が地頭を任免できる荘園・国衙領
sen.e: Kanto shinshishoryo - manors and Kokugaryo where shogun possessed the power to appoint and dismiss Jito.
Kanto shinshishoryo - manors and kokugaryo for which the shogun possessed the power to appoint and dismiss Jito.

sen.e: Kanto gokunyuchi - manors and provincial lands where the shogun of the Kamakura bakufu has the right to recommend Jito.

sen.e: Seii taishogun (Kamakura-dono)
Seii taishogun (Kamakura-dono)

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府の長。
sen.e: The leader of Kamakura bakufu.
The leader of Kamakura bakufu.

sen.j: 初代頼朝の時は実質的にトップだったが、その後形骸化していく。
sen.e: When Yoritomo was the first shogun, it was practically a top rank, but later became a mere façade.
When Yoritomo was the first shogun, it was practically a top rank, but later became a mere façade.
